article_title: With billions in surplus, health insurer defends nonprofit status
article_text:
With billions in surplus, health insurer defends nonprofit status Health plans dropped, rates raised in Texas despite huge reserves

Photo: Getty Images

Months before Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas' parent company sought to raise rates and shed coverage plans for hundreds of thousands of customers across its divisions, the Chicago-based nonprofit was sitting on a $9.9 billion surplus.

article_metadata.description: Months before Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas' parent company sought to raise rates and shed coverage plans coverage plans for hundreds of thousands of customers across its divisions, the Chicago-based nonprofit was sitting on a $9.9 billion surplus.  Health Care Service Corp. also had topped its previous year's revenues by 22 percent, bringing it to $27.7 billion, and gave its chief executive officer a $10 million bonus, according to its 2014 year-end financial statements and other documents.  Executives with HCSC said raising rates, dropping certain plans and narrowing networks for 2016 were necessary because losses in its individual plans are "unsustainable" and ultimately would put the company in financial peril.  Some in the midst of complex medical treatments say they specifically selected - and paid more for - preferred provider organization plans offered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas to get coverage at the city's renowned hospitals.  [...] he said his public criticism echoes the concerns raised by California officials who stripped Blue Shield of its tax-exempt status.  A lawsuit making its way through the Illinois court system alleges that HCSC has far exceeded the nonprofit boundaries and broken its promise to "operate on a non-profit basis for the mutual benefit of its members."  [...] last year, company CEO Patricia Hemingway Hall earned roughly $11.7 million, including more than $10 million in bonuses, Atlantic Information Services, a health care industry publishing and information company, confirmed last week.  According to the lawsuit, HCSC's total net income between 2009 and 2013 was about $4.5 billion.  Customers not only lost PPO coverage, but the replacement health maintenance organization plans exclude in-network coverage at some of the city's biggest names in the Texas Medical Center, including the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Texas Children's Hospital, Memorial Hermann and Houston Methodist, as well as hundreds of affiliated doctors.  Elsewhere, another division of HCSC, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Mexico, pulled all of its individual plans from that state's 2016 exchange after it failed to receive a 51.6 percent rate increase requested from the Office of Superintendent of Insurance.  The company said it had lost $19.2 million, according to published reports.  [...] another division, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois, eliminated its broadest-coverage PPO plan from that state's exchange, which removed in-network access to about half of the state's hospitals, including some of its most prestigious research and teaching facilities, the Chicago Tribune reported.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
